conclusion: To determine the temperature of the gas at state C, we need to analyze the given information and apply the principles of thermodynamics and the ideal gas law.
Temperature at state A, \( T_A = -73^\circ C = 200 \, \text{K} \).
Internal energy change from A to C, \( \Delta U = 200 \, \text{J} \).
Standard conditions: 1 mole of an ideal gas occupies 22.4 L at 1 atm and 273 K.

premise: From the ideal gas law at standard conditions: \[ PV = nRT \] \[ 1 \, \text{atm} \times 22.4 \, \text{L} = n \times 0.0821 \, \text{L} \cdot \text{atm} \cdot \text{K}^{-1} \cdot \text{mol}^{-1} \times 273 \, \text{K} \]

conclusion: The first law of thermodynamics states: \[ \Delta U = Q - W \].
From the p-V diagram, the pressure at state A is \( 3 \times 10^5 \, \text{Pa} \) and the volume change from A to C is \( 3 \times 10^{-3} \, \text{m}^3 \).

premise: The work done by the gas during the process from A to C is the area under the curve. Since the process is isobaric (constant pressure), the work done is: \[ W = P \Delta V \]
Using the first law of thermodynamics: \[ \Delta U = Q - W \] \[ 200 \, \text{J} = Q - 900 \, \text{J} \]

conclusion: At state C, the pressure is \( 1 \times 10^5 \, \text{Pa} \) and the volume is \( 4 \times 10^{-3} \, \text{m}^3 \).

premise: The ideal gas law is: \[ PV = nRT \] \[ 1 \times 10^5 \, \text{Pa} \times 4 \times 10^{-3} \, \text{m}^3 = 1 \, \text{mol} \times 8.314 \, \text{J} \cdot \text{K}^{-1} \cdot \text{mol}^{-1} \times T_C \]
